brief_description: The historic capital of Aquitaine and Europe's premier wine trading port, Bordeaux stands as a global icon of wine culture, neoclassical architecture, and refined French lifestyle. With its UNESCO World Heritage historic center, golden limestone facades, and centuries of viticultural heritage, Bordeaux continues to enchant visitors with an atmosphere that balances 18th-century grandeur with contemporary urban sophistication.
nickname: La Belle Endormie (The Sleeping Beauty) / Port de la Lune (Port of the Moon)

sections.title: A Living Wine Museum
sections.content: Bordeaux offers an unparalleled concentration of wine heritage within its compact city center. From the historic Chartrons district where wine merchants once operated to the contemporary Cité du Vin museum, the city's signature wine culture provides a backdrop to daily life. Beyond these famous sites, Bordeaux reveals itself through charming wine bars, hidden courtyards, and architectural wonders spanning centuries of viticultural history.

sections.title: Cultural Capital
sections.content: Home to world-class venues like the Grand Théâtre, Musée d'Aquitaine, and CAPC contemporary art museum, Bordeaux holds an unrivaled artistic heritage. The city continues its tradition as a center for creativity, with vibrant theater scenes, music venues, and independent galleries throughout its diverse districts. Bordeaux embraces both classical traditions and cutting-edge innovation across all art forms.

sections.title: Gastronomic Paradise
sections.content: Bordelais cuisine encompasses everything from traditional southwestern bistros to Michelin-starred establishments, historic wine bars to experimental fusion restaurants. The city celebrates food and wine as essential pleasures, whether enjoying café culture, exploring specialty food shops, or sampling the offerings at vibrant markets like Marché des Capucins or Marché des Quais.

sections.title: Elegant Lifestyle
sections.content: The Bordelais way of life emphasizes aesthetic appreciation and sensory pleasures. Residents and visitors alike embrace café terraces for people-watching, stroll through landscaped gardens like the Jardin Public, and appreciate the city's architectural harmony. Bordeaux balances cosmopolitan sophistication with everyday moments of beauty and leisure.

why_visit.intro: Bordeaux rewards visitors with experiences that range from grand wine spectacles to intimate discoveries, offering something for every type of traveler.

highlights.title: Iconic Wine Culture
highlights.content: The city's world-famous wine heritage provides unforgettable experiences, from touring the Cité du Vin to tasting at historic wine merchants in the Chartrons district. Each venue offers a unique perspective on Bordelais viticultural history and culture.

highlights.title: Architectural Treasures
highlights.content: Bordeaux houses some of France's greatest neoclassical achievements, from the Place de la Bourse to the Grand Théâtre. The city itself inspired countless architects, artists, and writers with its golden limestone beauty and harmonious urban planning.

highlights.title: Distinct Neighborhoods
highlights.content: Each Bordelais district offers its own character—from the medieval streets of Saint-Pierre to the elegant atmosphere of the Golden Triangle, the wine merchants of Chartrons to the multicultural energy of Saint-Michel.

highlights.title: Culinary Excellence
highlights.content: From morning croissants to evening wine tastings, Bordeaux celebrates exceptional food and wine experiences. Visitors can discover traditional southwestern classics, international influences, and innovative contemporary cuisine throughout the city.

highlights.title: Wine & Shopping
highlights.content: As a global wine capital, Bordeaux offers shopping experiences ranging from luxury wine boutiques to charming markets. The city's wine shops like L'Intendant are destinations in themselves, while neighborhoods like Saint-Pierre feature independent designers and artisanal products.

highlights.title: Riverside Beauty
highlights.content: The Garonne River provides a picturesque backdrop for exploration, whether strolling along the revitalized Quais de Bordeaux, relaxing in riverside gardens, or taking an evening boat cruise to see the illuminated neoclassical facades.

transport.public_transport: Bordeaux has an excellent public transportation network including trams, buses, and regional trains. The Tram is the fastest way to navigate the city with 3 lines serving 46 stations.
transport.passes: Consider the Bordeaux City Pass for unlimited travel or a day pass for pay-as-you-go options.

spring.description: Bordeaux blooms with flowering gardens and longer days perfect for outdoor exploration. Sidewalk cafés become lively social hubs, and the moderate temperatures make walking the city a pleasure.

summer.description: The city embraces outdoor living with special events like Bordeaux Plages (urban beaches) and open-air cinema along the Garonne. Longer daylight hours mean extended evening activities.
considerations: Some local businesses close in August

fall.description: Autumn brings comfortable temperatures and cultural renewal as museums launch new exhibitions. Parks display beautiful fall colors, and harvest-inspired menus appear in restaurants.

winter.description: Bordeaux offers a cozy atmosphere with festive holiday decorations, seasonal markets, and indoor cultural activities. Lower tourist numbers mean more authentic experiences at major attractions.
considerations: Some outdoor attractions have limited hours

best_time_to_visit.summary: Bordeaux shines in spring (April–June) and early fall (September–October), when café terraces buzz, gardens bloom or turn golden, and temperatures are comfortable for walking. July brings long evenings and big events but also peak crowds and higher prices; in August some boutiques and small restaurants close for holidays. Winter (November–February) is quieter and cozy—think museum days, wine tastings, and sparkling holiday lights—while March gradually warms with occasional showers.
